title: Informal Labor: Registration and Social Security Gap

formal_rule.text: La Ley de Contrato de Trabajo establece que todo empleador debe registrar trabajadores en seguridad social dentro de 5 días del inicio de la relación laboral, efectuando aportes del 23% del salario bruto.
formal_rule.source: Ley 20.744 - Ley de Contrato de Trabajo, Artículo 18
formal_rule.sanctions: Multas de $100,000 a $1,000,000 por trabajador no registrado (Ley 25.877)
formal_rule.scope: Todos los empleadores del sector privado, excepto servicio doméstico y trabajadores rurales

gap_quantification.metric: Percentage of workers without formal registration

informal_practice.regional_variation: Higher in northern provinces (Formosa 65%, Santiago del Estero 61%) vs Buenos Aires (35%)

sectoral_variation.description: Larger firms with better compliance systems

primary_causes: Limited inspection capacity (0.8% annual probability of workplace visit)
Administrative burden (18 hours/month compliance costs for small employers)
High labor taxes (45% total tax wedge including employer contributions)
Cultural acceptance of informal arrangements in small businesses
gap_analysis.enforcement_patterns: Inspections focus on large firms and formal complaints; micro-enterprises rarely audited
gap_analysis.temporal_trends: Slowly declining from 47% (2015) to 42% (2024), acceleration during economic recovery
gap_analysis.comparative_context: Similar to Brazil (39%) and Mexico (56%), higher than Chile (28%)

validation.verification_notes: Cross-checked with INDEC Q4 2024 data, ILO estimates (40%), and Ministry of Labor inspection statistics

reviewers.name: Dr. María González
reviewers.affiliation: Universidad de Buenos Aires - Derecho del Trabajo

english_abstract.formal: Argentine Labor Contract Law mandates employer registration of workers within 5 days and 23% salary contributions to social security, with penalties of $100,000-$1,000,000 per unregistered worker.
english_abstract.informal: 42% of workers (9 million people) operate without formal registration, varying by sector: construction (76.6%), domestic work (77%), commerce (51.9%), manufacturing (36.1%).
english_abstract.gap: Gap persists due to limited inspection capacity (0.8% annual probability), administrative burden (18 hours/month), high tax wedge (45%), and cultural acceptance of informality in micro-enterprises.
